ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to write strong, funny essays. I really appreciated this course.
I learned how to write better

I read many incredible short stories. I gained a lot from the discussions we had in class about how to analyze texts. With four essays, each with a second draft of edits, my writing improved significantly

Writing, writing, and writing -- how to choose compelling topics to write about, how to refine/improve these concepts, how to write a compelling piece (from both a stylistic and thematic standpoint), and how to edit that piece.
I learned how to develop a message, implement craft, and steal from authors' literary practices in order to create my own.
Key terms, concepts, and skills in creative nonfiction writing
Learned how to brainstorm, draft, and revise a nonfiction essay through close analysis of model essays & in-class workshops with my peers.

I was truly able to refine my writing process and understand the intricacies of creative writing. I learned the different syntax, tone, and styles available to evoke different emotions from the reader which created drastic improvement in my writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was great! I especially appreciate the ability to drop one of the unit essays.
The structure is great. The class is fun and engaging. Having five different units of different topics allows you to improve in many forms of writing. There is great feedback. Really no complaints

Strengths - the readings we went through were great (something there for everybody), the discussion was most of the time lively and engaged, the feedback process was helpful (especially for the essay you have to have peer reviewed)

The strength of the course was being able to practice different types of writing and different writing voices. The workshop method definitely helped improved my writing because I was constantly exposed to different critiques and feedback. 

The weakness was definitely the conversations we would have about the famous essays we would read. They would get redundant at times because it felt like the authors were employing the same methods. I wish we were given more space and time to critique their works and talk about ways they could've been made more effective.

Honestly I felt the course was structured well. I enjoyed the in-class discussions, group activities and workshops. My only suggestion would be to do even more group work in class; those activities were a lot of fun and I enjoyed bonding with my classmates.

Strengths: great selection of readings, wonderful classroom environment
Weaknesses: maybe a bit more structure in class? An hour and 15 minutes is long, so more structured activity & group discussion time would be appreciated.

There were many strengths of the course, including the workshops, writing exercises, and readings in general. Not any weaknesses I can think of beside maybe cutting a few readings for times sake because I know a few were rushed. I understand the difficulty of that though because we are trying to see all of the different styles.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Take for the writing credit
Yes
Yes, great reading, great class structure of discussions, great teacher

I would - there are easier writing credits out there, if that's your thing. But if you're up for a little bit of a challenge, you should without a doubt take ENGL 120. Your writing will definitely improve, which is super satisfying to watch. The class atmosphere is great, very friendly and engaging. Plus it's English at Yale! Even if you're not an English major, it's worth checking out what all the fuss is about and why our program is considered top-notch.
If you want to get back into writing, this is the course to take. There is a lot of room given to you to grow and explore different writing styles/structures.

Absolutely, this is a wonderful class that helps you explore your creative side and engage in your personal life in a way that sets you up for all other creative nonfiction writing you may do in your life
100%  if you're looking for a good WR credit or to improve your creative nonfiction skills in general, ENGL 120 is a fantastic choice.
Yes, this course is fantastic and although there is a lot of reading and writing, it is not overwhelming because it is spaced out and very engaging.
